DataElement.preferredName: Breast Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Pathologic Distant Metastasis M Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the distant metastasis for the breast carcinoma based on evidence obtained from pathologic examination through completion of definitive surgery.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information related to pathologic M stage of a breast tumor.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pathologic; caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.:One criteria of the TMN staging system.  M refers to the presence of metastasis.

Concepts.definition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 11/17/17 tt associated with CS/CSI. 9/13/17 tt transferred context; changed def - 1st letter upper case; changed Reg Status to Qualified.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Breast Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Pathologic M Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A pathologic finding about one or more characteristics of breast cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system as they pertain to distant metastases. TNM pathologic distant metastasis findings are based on clinical findings supplemented by histopathologic examination of one or more tissue specimens acquired during surgery._A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Breast cancer with distant metastasis. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

Concepts.longName: Breast Cancer pM1 TNM Finding v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Breast cancer with distant metastasis. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

TNM pathologic distant metastasis findings are based on clinical findings supplemented by histopathologic examination of one or more tissue specimens acquired during surgery.:A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.longName: Breast Cancer Pathologic Distant Metastasis TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: A pathologic finding about one or more characteristics of breast cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system as they pertain to distant metastases. TNM pathologic distant metastasis findings are based on clinical findings supplemented by histopathologic examination of one or more tissue specimens acquired during surgery.
A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
